data.title: Anna Kendall (Lee) Armistead (1681-1754)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Anna (Lee) Armistead born 1681 Ditchley, Northumberland County, Virginia Colony died 1754 Kingston Parish, Gloucester County, Virginia Colony including ancestors + descendants + 7 genealogist comments + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 30 Oct 2023 | Created 29 Jul 2011

This page has been accessed 4,124 times.

The Birth Date is a rough estimate. See the text for details.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Research Notes

1.2 Origin

1.3 Marriages and Children

1.4 Residence

1.5 Death and Legacy

2 Sources

Biography

Anna (Lee) Armistead was a Virginia colonist.

Research Notes

Modern history have commended the skill exercised by the men of the Lee family in selecting their wives. Anna is an example of what a young girl could do in those days. By her marriage to William Armistead of Eastmost River, Anna became the sister-in-law of King Carter, Ralph Wormeley, and William Churchill. The Cotillon Leaders of the Rappahannock in that era by this marriage she had a daughter, Mary, who married Phillip Lightfoot. Member of the council, friend and cousin of Thomas Lee of Stratford. William Armistead died 1711, leaving Anna with children; she then married William Eustace, who died 1740. From the second union there were three sons, William, Hancock, and Isaac Eustace. This family will later cross again through Mary and Phillip Lightfoot (from FamilySearch.org, 5 Aug 2013).

In the past, researchers have assumed that Anna and Anne were identical.[1] A very well-written article by James R. Hancock, using primary documents, has solved the question of Anna and Anne Lee.[2] He shows they are two different women, half-sisters.

Anna Lee (and also included Ann and Anne in the data field for Other Nicknames to help find and prevent duplicates).

There were two different daughters of Hancock Lee, this one named Anna Lee, was a daughter of his 1st wife, Mary Kendall. She married William Armstead.

The other named Anne Lee was a daughter of 2nd wife, Sarah Allerton. She married William Eustace.[2]

Origin

Ann was born before 1682, at Ditchley, Northumberland County, Virginia. She was a daughter of Hancock Lee and Mary Kendall.[2]

Per the sources on her father, Hancock's profile, Ann was born Anna, prior to January 5, 1682 and was living as late as October 1754.

Marriages and Children

Anna married only once.

She married before 1706 to William Armstead.[2][3] He died on 13 June 1711.[2]"William Armistead in the U.S. and International Marriage Records, 1560-1900." William Armistead in the U.S. and International Marriage Records, 1560-1900. N.p., n.d. Web. 18 May. 2017. <http://search.ancestry.com/collections/7836/records/30620>.

Children of Anna and William Armstead:[2]

John Armstead

Mary Armstead

Judith Armstead

Anna Armstead

Joyce Armstead

Frances Armstead

Francis Armstead

Residence

Anna lived at her husband's home in Kingston Parish, Gloucester County, Virginia Colony.[2]

Death and Legacy

Anna died at Kingston Parish, Gloucester County, Virginia Colony.[2]

Sources

↑ Merrick, Barbara Lambert, 1992 Important Allerton/Brewster Corrections. The Mayflower Descendant ... (Vol 42, Pages 117) Boston, MA: Massachusetts Society of Mayflower Descendants, 1899- . (Online database accessed 13 February 2016: AmericanAncestors.org, NEHGS, 2010) Note: Does not report the two different daughters, Anna and Anne Lee.

↑ 2.0 2.1 2.2 2.3 2.4 2.5 2.6 2.7 Hancock, James Reid, 2010 http://www.americanancestors.org/databases/mayflower-descendant-the/image/?volumeId=30243&pageName=13&rId=723631298 Ann (Lee) Eustace, Daughter of Hancock Lee of Northumberland Co., Va. and His Second Wife Sarah Allerton: Genealogical Summary. The Mayflower Descendant ... (Vol 59, Page 13) Boston, MA: Massachusetts Society of Mayflower Descendants, 1899- . (Online database accessed 13 February 2016: AmericanAncestors.org, NEHGS, 2010).

↑ Marriage

Mayflower Families Vol. 17 p. 22.
